      6c
      Metal-Organic Polyhedral Frameworks: High H2 Adsorption Capacities and Neutron Powder Diffraction Studies
      Yan, Yong; Telepeni, Irvin; Yang, Sihai; Lin, Xiang; Kockelmann, Winfried; Dailly, Anne; Blake, Alexander J.; Lewis, William; Walker, Gavin S.; Allan, David R.; Barnett, Sarah A.; Champness, Neil R.; Schroder, Martin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (12), 4092-4094CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The metal-org. polyhedral framework complex [Cu3(L)(H2O)3]·16DMF·26H2O (NOTT-112, H6L = 1,3,5-tris(4-(3,5-dicarboxyphenylethynyl)phenyl)benzene) was prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog. and hydrogen adsorption expts. Neutron powder diffraction expts. on D2-loaded NOTT-112 reveal that the axial sites of exposed Cu(II) ions in the smallest cuboctahedral cages are the 1st, strongest binding sites for D2 leading to an overall discrimination between the two types of exposed Cu(II) sites at the paddlewheel nodes. Thus, the Cu(II) centers within the cuboctahedral cage are the 1st sites of D2 binding with a Cu-D2 distance of 2.23(1) Å.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXis1Oqu7k%253D&md5=215f7876ac3dc27255674de9b72a8095
      (d) Yan, Y.; Blake, A. J.; Lewis, W.; Barnett, S. A.; Dailly, A.; Champness, N. R.; Schröder, M. Chem. - Eur. J. 2011, 17, 11162– 11170 DOI: 10.1002/chem.201101341
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6d
      Modifying Cage Structures in Metal-Organic Polyhedral Frameworks for H2 Storage
      Yan, Yong; Blake, Alexander J.; Lewis, William; Barnett, Sarah A.; Dailly, Anne; Champness, Neil R.; Schroeder, Martin
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2011), 17 (40), 11162-11170, S11162/1-S11162/9CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Three isostructural metal-org. polyhedral cage based frameworks (denoted NOTT-113, NOTT-114 and NOTT-115) with (3,24)-connected topol. have been synthesized by combining hexacarboxylate isophthalate linkers with {Cu2(RCOO)4} paddlewheels. All three frameworks have the same cuboctahedral cage structure constructed from 24 isophthalates from the ligands and 12 {Cu2(RCOO)4} paddlewheel moieties. The frameworks differ only in the functionality of the central core of the hexacarboxylate ligands with trimethylphenyl, phenylamine and triphenylamine moieties in NOTT-113, NOTT-114 and NOTT-115, resp. Exchange of pore solvent with acetone followed by heating affords the corresponding desolvated framework materials, which show high BET surface areas of 2970, 3424 and 3394 m2 g-1 for NOTT-113, NOTT-114 and NOTT-115, resp. Desolvated NOTT-113 and NOTT-114 show high total H2 adsorption capacities of 6.7 and 6.8 wt %, resp., at 77 K and 60 bar. Desolvated NOTT-115 has a significantly higher total H2 uptake of 7.5 wt % under the same conditions. Anal. of the heats of adsorption (Qst) for H2 reveals that with a triphenylamine moiety in the cage wall, desolvated NOTT-115 shows the highest value of Qst for these three materials, indicating that functionalization of the cage walls with more arom. rings can enhance the H2/framework interactions. In contrast, measurement of Qst reveals that the amine-substituted trisalkynylbenzene core used in NOTT-114 gives a notably lower H2/framework binding energy.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXhtFersLnN&md5=41279c4a9bb33734f3e9067da11ccfef
      (e) Yan, Y.; Yang, S.; Blake, A. J.; Lewis, W.; Poirier, E.; Barnett, S. A.; Champness, N. R.; Schröder, M. Chem. Commun. 2011, 47, 9995– 9997 DOI: 10.1039/c1cc13170b
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      A mesoporous metal-organic framework constructed from a nanosized C3-symmetric linker and [Cu24(isophthalate)24] cuboctahedra
      Yan, Yong; Yang, Sihai; Blake, Alexander J.; Lewis, William; Poirier, Eric; Barnett, Sarah A.; Champness, Neil R.; Schroeder, Martin
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2011), 47 (36), 9995-9997CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The newly prepd. mesoporous framework [Cu3(L)(H2O)3]·(DMF)35·(H2O)35 (L = 1,3,5-tris(3,5-dicarboxylate-p-biphenylene)benzene) (NOTT-119) shows on desolvation a BET surface area of 4118(200) m2/g-1, a pore vol. of 2.35 cm3/g-1, a total H2 uptake of 101 mg/g-1 at 60 bar, 77 K and a total CH4 uptake of 327 mg/g-1 at 80 bar, 298 K.

      6f
      Modulating the packing of [Cu24(isophthalate)24] cuboctahedra in a triazole-containing metal-organic polyhedral framework
      Yan, Yong; Suyetin, Mikhail; Bichoutskaia, Elena; Blake, Alexander J.; Allan, David R.; Barnett, Sarah A.; Schroeder, Martin
      Chemical Science (2013), 4 (4), 1731-1736CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The highly porous (3,24)-connected framework NOTT-122 (I) was prepd. from a reaction product of 1,3,5-triethynylbenzene, 5-azidoisophthalic acid, and tris[(1-benzyl-1H-1,2,3-triazol-4-yl)methyl]amine and Cu(NO3)2.2.5H2O. Crystal data of I: tetragonal, I4/m, a = 30.926(5), c = 45.103(7) Å, Z = 16, 18,798 independent reflections, 553 refined parameters, R1 = 0.065, wR2 = 0.189. Compd. I incorporates a C3-sym. angularly connected isophthalate linker contg. 1,2,3-triazole rings and shows body-centered tetragonal packing of [Cu24(isophthalate)24] cuboctahedra. This unique packing, coupled with the high d. of free N-donor sites, is responsible for the simultaneous high H2, CH4, and CO2 adsorption capacities in desolvated I (NOTT-122a).

      7a
      Symmetry-Guided Synthesis of Highly Porous Metal-Organic Frameworks with Fluorite Topology
      Zhang, Muwei; Chen, Ying-Pin; Bosch, Mathieu; Gentle, Thomas, III; Wang, Kecheng; Feng, Dawei; Wang, Zhiyong U.; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2014), 53 (3), 815-818CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Two stable, non-interpenetrated MOFs, PCN-521 and PCN-523, were synthesized by a symmetry-guided strategy. Augmentation of the 4-connected nodes in the fluorite structure with a rigid tetrahedral ligand and substitution of the 8-connected nodes by the Zr/Hf clusters yielded MOFs with large octahedral interstitial cavities. They are the first examples of Zr/Hf MOFs with tetrahedral linkers. PCN-521 has the largest BET surface area (3411 m2 g-1), pore size (20.5 × 20.5 × 37.4 Å) and void vol. (78.5 %) of MOFs formed from tetrahedral ligands. This work not only demonstrates a successful implementation of rational design of MOFs with desired topol., but also provides a systematic way of constructing non-interpenetrated MOFs with high porosity.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhslOlsLvL&md5=a2ca509ef844d985ecdfc46e5b0e7971
      (b) Dincă, M.; Dailly, A.; Long, J. R. Chem. - Eur. J. 2008, 14, 10280– 10285 DOI: 10.1002/chem.200801336
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7b
      Structure and charge control in metal-organic frameworks based on the tetrahedral ligand tetrakis(4-tetrazolylphenyl)methane
      Dinca, Mircea; Dailly, Anne; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2008), 14 (33), 10280-10285CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Use of the tetrahedral ligand tetrakis(4-tetrazolylphenyl)methane enabled isolation of two three-dimensional metal-org. frameworks featuring 4,6- and 4,8-connected nets related to the structures of garnet and fluorite, Mn6(ttpm)3·5DMF·3H2O (1) and Cu[(Cu4Cl)(ttpm)2]2·CuCl2·5DMF·11H2O (2, H4ttpm = tetrakis(4-tetrazolylphenyl)methane). The fluorite-type solid 2 displays an unprecedented post-synthetic transformation in which the neg. charge of the framework is reduced by extn. of copper(II) chloride. Desolvation of this compd. generates Cu4(ttpm)2·0.7CuCl2 (2d), a microporous material exhibiting a high surface area and significant hydrogen uptake.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      8a
      Framework-Catenation Isomerism in Metal-Organic Frameworks and Its Impact on Hydrogen Uptake
      Ma, Shengqian; Sun, Daofeng; Ambrogio, Michael; Fillinger, Jacqueline A.; Parkin, Sean; Zhou, Hong-Cai
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (7), 1858-1859CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A strategy to control framework-catenation in metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) was presented; contributions to H uptake from interpenetration and unsatd. metal centers were resolved. Non-interpenetrated counterpart of Cu3(TATB)2(H2O)3, Cu6(H2O)6(TATB)4·DMA·12H2O (I; H3TATB = 4,4',4''-s-triazine-2,4,6-trityltribenzoic acid; DMA = dimethylacetamide), was prepd. by the reaction of Cu(NO3)2 with H3TATB in presence of oxalic acid. The crystal structure of I was detd. In I the dicopper tetracarboxylate paddle-wheel secondary building units are linked by TATB bridges and each secondary building unit connects 4 TATB ligands and each TATB binds 3 secondary building units. The uptake of H2 by I was compared with that of Cu3(TATB)2(H2O)3, the latter being reproduced by 2 identical interpenetrated nets of I.

      Isoreticular Expansion of Metal-Organic Frameworks with Triangular and Square Building Units and the Lowest Calculated Density for Porous Crystals
      Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Go, Yong Bok; Ko, Nakeun; Park, Young Kwan; Uribe-Romo, Fernando J.; Kim, Jaheon; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Inorganic Chemistry (2011), 50 (18), 9147-9152CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
      The concept and occurrence of isoreticular (same topol.) series of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) is reviewed. The authors describe the prepn., characterization, and crystal structures of three new MOFs that are isoreticular expansions of known materials with the tbo (Cu3(4,4',4''-(benzene-1,3,5-triyl-tris(benzene-4,1-diyl))tribenzoate)2, MOF-399)and pto topologies (Cu3(4,4',4''-(benzene-1,3,5-triyl-tribenzoate))2), MOF-143; (Cu3(4,4',4''-(triazine-2,4,6-triyl-tris(benzene-4,1-diyl))tribenzoate)2, MOF-388). One of (MOF-399) has a unit cell vol. 17 times larger than that of the 1st reported material isoreticular to it, and has the highest porosity (94%) and lowest d. (0.126 g cm-3) of any MOFs reported to date.

      9a
      A Metal-Organic Framework with Covalently Bound Organometallic Complexes
      Oisaki, Kounosuke; Li, Qiaowei; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Czaja, Alexander U.; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (27), 9262-9264CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A procedure for making covalently linked organometallic complexes within the pores of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) has been described. An N-heterocyclic carbene precursor contg. link I was prepd. and then constructed into a MOF-5-type structure (IRMOF-76). Attempts to produce covalently bound organometallic complexes in IRMOF-76 were unsuccessful. An alternative way of linking the first metalated link, palladium-NHC complex II, into the desired metalated MOF structure, IRMOF-77, was successful. IRMOF-76 and -77 were characterized by single-crystal x-ray studies. Demonstration of permanent porosity and successful substitution of the pyridine coligand in IRMOF-77 are also described.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXnsFyhtL0%253D&md5=bb5a99422f2766efb5eb706e9c847381
      (b) Farha, O. K.; Malliakas, C. D.; Kanatzidis, M. G.; Hupp, J. T. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2010, 132, 950– 952 DOI: 10.1021/ja909519e
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9b
      Control over Catenation in Metal-Organic Frameworks via Rational Design of the Organic Building Block
      Farha, Omar K.; Malliakas, Christos D.; Kanatzidis, Mercouri G.; Hupp, Joseph T.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (3), 950-952CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), a hybrid class of materials comprising inorg. nodes and org. struts, have potential application in many areas due to their high surface areas and uniform pores and channels. One of the key challenges to be overcome in MOF synthesis is the strong propensity for catenation (growth of multiple independent networks within a given crystal), as catenation reduces cavity sizes and diminishes porosity. Rational design of org. building blocks, which act as strut-impervious scaffolds, can be exploited to generate highly desired noncatenated materials in a controlled fashion. Eight metal-org. framework materials, [Zn2(Lbp)(Lta)]n (Lbp = 4,4'-bipyridine, azobis(4-pyridine), 3,6-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4,5-tetrazine and N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetracarboxylic 1,8:4,5-diimide; Lta = 1,2,4,5-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (L5) and 3,6-dibromo-1,2,4,5-tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (L6)) were prepd. and characterized by x-ray crystallog. and porosity measurements. The four MOFs with L5 had 2-fold catenated structures, while the four with L6 were noncatenated. The addn. of bromines to the tetraacid suppressed undesired catenation.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhs1altbnE&md5=17eb6d10af50755b346a9986e3c5be10
    10. 10
      Grunder, S.; Valente, C.; Whalley, A. C.; Sampath, S.; Portmann, J.; Botros, Y. Y.; Stoddart, J. F. Chem. - Eur. J. 2012, 18, 15632– 15649 DOI: 10.1002/chem.201201985
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      10
      Molecular Gauge Blocks for Building on the Nanoscale
      Grunder, Sergio; Valente, Cory; Whalley, Adam C.; Sampath, Srinivasan; Portmann, Juerg; Botros, Youssry Y.; Stoddart, J. Fraser
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (49), 15632-15649, S15632/1-S15632/48CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Mol. gauge blocks, based on 1-7, 9-11 paraxylene rings, were synthesized as part of a homologous series of oligoparaxylenes (OPXs) with a view to providing a mol. tool box for the construction of nano architectures-such as spheres, cages, capsules, metal-org. frameworks (MOFs), metal-org. polyhedrons (MOPs) and covalent-org. frameworks (COFs), to name but a few-of well-defined sizes and shapes. Twisting between the planes of contiguous paraxylene rings is generated by the steric hindrance assocd. with the Me groups and leads to the existence of sol. mol. gauge blocks without the need, at least in the case of the lower homologs, to introduce long aliph. side chains onto the phenylene rings in the mols. Although sol. mol. gauge blocks with up to seven consecutive benzenoid rings were prepd. employing repeating paraxylene units, in the case of the higher homologs it becomes necessary to introduce hexyl groups instead of Me groups onto selected phenylene rings to maintain soly. A hexyl-doped compd. with seven substituted phenylene rings is an organogelator, exhibiting thermally reversible gelation and a crit. gelation concn. of 10 mM in DMSO. Also, control over the morphol. of hexyl-doped OPXs to give microfibers, microaggregates, or nanofibers, were obsd. as a function of their lengths according to images obtained by SEM. The modular syntheses of the paraphenylene derivs. rely heavily on Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions. The lack of π-π conjugation in these derivs. that is responsible for their enhanced solubilities was corroborated by UV/visible and fluorescent spectroscopy. In one particular series of model OPXs, dynamic 1H NMR spectroscopy was used to probe the stereochem. consequences of having from one up to five axes of chirality present in the same mol. The Losanitsch sequence for the compds. with 1-3 chiral axes was established, and a contemporary math. way was found to describe the sequence. The development of the ways and means to make mol. gauge building blocks will have pos. repercussions on the control of nanostructures in general. Their incorporation into extended structures with the MOF-74 topol. provides an excellent demonstration of the potential usefulness of these mol. gauge blocks.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhsFGktrzJ&md5=75871745187a7c22324b660e3ee4eb04
    11. 11
      Deng, H.; Grunder, S.; Cordova, K. E.; Valente, C.; Furukawa, H.; Hmadeh, M.; Gándara, F.; Whalley, A. C.; Liu, Z.; Asahina, S.; Kazumori, H.; O’Keeffe, M.; Terasaki, O.; Stoddart, J. F.; Yaghi, O. M. Science 2012, 336, 1018– 1023 DOI: 10.1126/science.1220131
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      11
      Large-Pore Apertures in a Series of Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Deng, Hexiang; Grunder, Sergio; Cordova, Kyle E.; Valente, Cory; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Hmadeh, Mohamad; Gandara, Felipe; Whalley, Adam C.; Liu, Zheng; Asahina, Shunsuke; Kazumori, Hiroyoshi; O'Keeffe, Michael; Terasaki, Osamu; Stoddart, J. Fraser; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 336 (6084), 1018-1023CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      The authors report a strategy to expand the pore aperture of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) into a previously unattained size regime (>32 Å). Specifically, the systematic expansion of a known MOF structure, MOF-74, from its original link of one phenylene ring (I) to two, three, four, five, six, seven, nine, and eleven (II to XI, resp.), afforded an isoreticular series of Mg- or Zn-contg. MOF-74 structures (termed IRMOF-74-I to -XI) with pore apertures ranging from 14 to 98 Å. All members of this series have noninterpenetrating structures and exhibit robust architectures, as evidenced by their permanent porosity and high thermal stability (up to 300°). The pore apertures of an oligoethylene glycol-functionalized IRMOF-74-VII and IRMOF-74-IX are large enough for natural proteins to enter the pores.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xnt1Kgt7s%253D&md5=be82c139a536be7009991c48606c3829
    12. 12
      Lörtscher, E.; Elbing, M.; Tschudy, M.; von Hänisch, C.; Weber, H. B.; Mayor, M.; Riel, H. ChemPhysChem 2008, 9, 2252– 2258 DOI: 10.1002/cphc.200800388
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      12
      Charge transport through molecular rods with reduced π-conjugation
      Lortscher, Emanuel; Elbing, Mark; Tschudy, Meinrad; von Hanisch, Carsten; Weber, Heiko B.; Mayor, Marcel; Riel, Heike
      ChemPhysChem (2008), 9 (15), 2252-2258CODEN: CPCHFT; ISSN:1439-4235. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A series of oligophenylene rods of increasing lengths is synthesized to investigate the charge-transport mechanisms. Me groups are attached to the Ph rings to weaken the electronic overlap of the π-subsystems along the mol. backbones. Out-of-plane rotation of the Ph rings is confirmed in the solid state by means of X-ray anal. and in soln. by using UV/Vis spectroscopy. The influence of the reduced π-conjugation on the resonant charge transport is studied at the single-mol. level by using the mech. controllable break-junction technique. Expts. are performed under ultra-high-vacuum conditions at low temp. (50 K). A linear increase of the conductance gap with increasing no. of Ph rings (from 260 meV for one ring to 580 meV for four rings) is revealed. In addn., the abs. conductance of the first resonant peaks does not depend on the length of the mol. wire. Resonant transport through the first MO is found to be dominated by charge-carrier injection into the mol., rather than by the intrinsic resistance of the mol. wire length.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtlOqt7nL&md5=8a1e415049d8fc3f83171da55f79208a

      (a) Reid, C. R.; Thomas, K. M. Langmuir 1999, 15, 3206– 3218 DOI: 10.1021/la981289p
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13a
      Adsorption of Gases on a Carbon Molecular Sieve Used for Air Separation: Linear Adsorptives as Probes for Kinetic Selectivity
      Reid, C. R.; Thomas, K. M.
      Langmuir (1999), 15 (9), 3206-3218CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
      The adsorption of oxygen, nitrogen, and a series of gases/vapors with linear structures (carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide, acetylene and carbon disulfide) on a carbon mol. sieve typical of the materials used for air sepn. were studied over a range of temps. as a function of pressure in order to understand further the mechanism of air sepn. The ratios of the rate consts. (kO2/kN2) were typically 25 for the carbon mol. sieve used thereby demonstrating the mol. sieving characteristics. The adsorption kinetics obey a linear driving force (LDF) mass transfer model for most of the gases and exptl. conditions studied. However there were deviations from the LDF model for carbon dioxide and nitrous oxide. In the case of the former, the kinetic models ranged from LDF through a combined barrier resistance/diffusion model to Fickian diffusion depending on the exptl. conditions. The adsorption rate consts. increase exponentially with increasing surface coverage for the mols. which follow the LDF model. The barrier resistance kinetic consts. derived from the combined barrier resistance/diffusion model also have an exponential dependence on surface coverage. The results are discussed in terms of the mechanism of gas sepn. using carbon mol. sieves.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1MXitVags7k%253D&md5=05483b1753869f8ee0dc743fbc200391
      (b) Reid, C. R.; Thomas, K. M. J. Phys. Chem. B 2001, 105, 10619– 10629 DOI: 10.1021/jp0108263
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      13b
      Adsorption Kinetics and Size Exclusion Properties of Probe Molecules for the Selective Porosity in a Carbon Molecular Sieve Used for Air Separation
      Reid, C. R.; Thomas, K. M.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry B (2001), 105 (43), 10619-10629CODEN: JPCBFK; ISSN:1089-5647. (American Chemical Society)
      The adsorption characteristics of planar (ethylene, benzene, and pyridine) and tetrahedral (methane, chloromethane, dichloromethane, chloroform, and carbon tetrachloride) mols. on a carbon mol. sieve used for air sepn. (CMS A) were studied over a range of temps. as a function of pressure, to study the selective porosity. The size-exclusion characteristics of planar and tetrahedral mols. indicate that the selective porosity behaves as though it has spherical-shaped structural characteristics and, therefore, two min. dimensions need to be considered in relation to size exclusion. The partial exclusion of the probe mol. adsorptives from the microporous structure for sizes >360 pm allowed the selective and nonselective microporosity and the meso/macroporosity to be quantified. Adsorption kinetics obey a linear-driving-force mass transfer, combined barrier resistance/diffusion, or Fickian kinetic models depending on the adsorptive and exptl. conditions. Comparison of the results with previous studies of the adsorption of linear and spherical mols. on CMS A show that a decrease in the adsorption rate const. of ∼4 orders of magnitude was obsd. for an increase in mol. size over the range ∼290-420 pm. The activation energies and preexponential factors for the adsorption kinetics and the isosteric heats of adsorption are discussed in terms of the structural characteristics of the adsorptives and the adsorption mechanism.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      (a) Sheldrick, G. M.SHELXL2013: Program for Refinement of Crystal Structures; University of Göttingen: Göttingen, Germany, 2013.
      Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      (b) Sheldrick, G. M. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A: Found. Crystallogr. 2008, 64, 112– 122 DOI: 10.1107/S0108767307043930
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      14b
      A short history of SHELX
      Sheldrick, George M.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
      An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhsVGhurzO&md5=8f91f10be4a9df74b2a9dad522c71e6e
    15. 15
      Spek, A. L. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. C 2015, 71, 9– 18 DOI: 10.1107/S2053229614024929
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      15
      PLATON SQUEEZE: a tool for the calculation of the disordered solvent contribution to the calculated structure factors
      Spek, Anthony L.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section C: Structural Chemistry (2015), 71 (1), 9-18CODEN: ACSCGG; ISSN:2053-2296. (International Union of Crystallography)
      The completion of a crystal structure detn. is often hampered by the presence of embedded solvent mols. or ions that are seriously disordered. Their contribution to the calcd. structure factors in the least-squares refinement of a crystal structure has to be included in some way. Traditionally, an atomistic solvent disorder model is attempted. Such an approach is generally to be preferred, but it does not always lead to a satisfactory result and may even be impossible in cases where channels in the structure are filled with continuous electron d. This paper documents the SQUEEZE method as an alternative means of addressing the solvent disorder issue. It conveniently interfaces with the 2014 version of the least-squares refinement program SHELXL [Sheldrick (2015). Acta Cryst. C71. In the press] and other refinement programs that accept externally provided fixed contributions to the calcd. structure factors. The PLATON SQUEEZE tool calcs. the solvent contribution to the structure factors by back-Fourier transformation of the electron d. found in the solvent-accessible region of a phase-optimized difference electron-d. map. The actual least-squares structure refinement is delegated to, for example, SHELXL. The current versions of PLATON SQUEEZE and SHELXL now address several of the unnecessary complications with the earlier implementation of the SQUEEZE procedure that were a necessity because least-squares refinement with the now superseded SHELXL97 program did not allow for the input of fixed externally provided contributions to the structure-factor calcn. It is no longer necessary to subtract the solvent contribution temporarily from the obsd. intensities to be able to use SHELXL for the least-squares refinement, since that program now accepts the solvent contribution from an external file ( file) if the ABIN instruction is used. In addn., many twinned structures contg. disordered solvents are now also treatable by SQUEEZE. The details of a SQUEEZE calcn. are now automatically included in the CIF archive file, along with the unmerged reflection data. The current implementation of the SQUEEZE procedure is described, and discussed and illustrated with three examples. Two of them are based on the reflection data of published structures and one on synthetic reflection data generated for a published structure.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXjvFejtw%253D%253D&md5=88200a7c2b687d49b1dedf1a7b7fa38d

      (a) Ortiz, A. U.; Boutin, A.; Fuchs, A. H.; Coudert, F.-X. J. Chem. Phys. 2013, 138, 174703 DOI: 10.1063/1.4802770
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16a
      Metal-organic frameworks with wine-rack motif: What determines their flexibility and elastic properties?
      Ortiz, Aurelie U.; Boutin, A.; Fuchs, Alain H.; Coudert, Francois-Xavier
      Journal of Chemical Physics (2013), 138 (17), 174703/1-174703/8CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606. (American Institute of Physics)
      The authors present here a framework for the anal. of the full tensors of 2nd-order elastic consts. of metal-org. frameworks, which can be obtained by ab initio DFT calcns. The authors describe the various mech. properties one can derive from such tensors: directional Young's modulus, shear modulus, Poisson ratio, and linear compressibility. The authors then apply this methodol. to four different metal-org. frameworks displaying a wine-rack structure: MIL-53(Al), MIL-47, MIL-122(In), and MIL-140A. The authors shed some light into the link between mech. properties, geometric shape, and compliance of the framework of these porous solids. The authors conclude by proposing a simple criterion to assess the framework compliance, based on the lowest eigenvalue of its 2nd-order elastic tensor. (c) 2013 American Institute of Physics.

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16b
      Anisotropic elastic properties of flexible metal-organic frameworks: how soft are soft porous crystals?
      Ortiz, Aurelie U.; Boutin, Anne; Fuchs, Alain H.; Coudert, Francois-Xavier
      Physical Review Letters (2012), 109 (19), 195502/1-195502/5CODEN: PRLTAO; ISSN:0031-9007. (American Physical Society)
      Elastic consts. of MIL-53(Al), MIL-53(Ga), MIL-47, and the square and lozenge structures of DMOF-1 have been detd. using ab initio methods. Tensorial anal. of the elastic consts. revealed a highly anisotropic elastic behavior, some deformation directions exhibiting very low Young's modulus and shear modulus. The anisotropy reached a 400:1 ratio between the most rigid and weakest directions, in stark contrast to the case of nonflexible MOFs such as MOF-5 and ZIF-8. Flexible MOFs were shown to display extremely large neg. linear compressibility. These results showed the microscopic roots of stimuli-induced structural transitions in flexible MOFs, by linking the local elastic behavior of the material and its multistability.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xhslymu7bE&md5=6cbb661bb093723027a3a70c03dff176

      Tan, J.-C.; Civalleri, B.; Lin, C.-C.; Valenzano, L.; Galvelis, R.; Chen, P.-F.; Bennett, T. D.; Mellot-Draznieks, C.; Zicovich-Wilson, C. M.; Cheetham, A. K. Phys. Rev. Lett. 2012, 108, 095502 DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.095502
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Exceptionally low shear modulus in a prototypical imidazole-based metal-organic framework
      Tan, Jin-Chong; Civalleri, Bartolomeo; Lin, Chung-Cherng; Valenzano, Loredana; Galvelis, Raimondas; Chen, Po-Fei; Bennett, Thomas D.; Mellot-Draznieks, Caroline; Zicovich-Wilson, Claudio M.; Cheetham, Anthony K.
      Physical Review Letters (2012), 108 (9), 095502/1-095502/6CODEN: PRLTAO; ISSN:0031-9007. (American Physical Society)
      Using Brillouin scattering, we measured the single-crystal elastic consts. (Cij's) of a prototypical metal-org. framework (MOF): zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF)-8 [Zn(2-methylimidazolate)2], which adopts a zeolitic sodalite topol. and exhibits large porosity. Its Cij's under ambient conditions are (in GPa) C11 = 9.522(7), C12 = 6.865(14), and C44 = 0.967(4). Tensorial anal. of the Cij's reveals the complete picture of the anisotropic elasticity in cubic ZIF-8. The authors show that ZIF-8 has a remarkably low shear modulus Gmin .ltorsim. 1 GPa, which is the lowest yet reported for a single-cryst. extended solid. Using ab initio calcns., the authors demonstrate that ZIF-8's Cij's can be reliably predicted, and its elastic deformation mechanism is linked to the pliant ZnN4 tetrahedra. The results shed new light on the role of elastic consts. in establishing the structural stability of MOF materials and thus their suitability for practical applications.

      Ogborn, J. M.; Collings, I. E.; Moggach, S. A.; Thompson, A. L.; Goodwin, A. L. Chem. Sci. 2012, 3, 3011– 3017 DOI: 10.1039/c2sc20596c
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      18
      Supramolecular mechanics in a metal-organic framework
      Ogborn, Joseph M.; Collings, Ines E.; Moggach, Stephen A.; Thompson, Amber L.; Goodwin, Andrew L.
      Chemical Science (2012), 3 (10), 3011-3017CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A combination of variable-temp. and variable-pressure single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction is used to study the thermo- and piezo-mech. properties of the metal-org. framework (MOF) silver(i) 2-methylimidazolate, Ag(mim). We find the material to exhibit a no. of anomalous mech. properties: neg. thermal expansion, colossal pos. thermal expansion and the most extreme neg. linear compressibility yet obsd. for a MOF. By considering the mech. response of individual supramol. motifs we are able to rationalise the varied and unconventional behavior of the bulk material. A general inverse correspondence between strength of supramol. interaction and magnitude of mech. response is identified. We propose that the consideration of MOF structures in terms of their underlying mech. building units provides a straightforward qual. method of directing framework design in order to maximise anomalous mech. response.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Bouëssel du Bourg, L.; Ortiz, A. U.; Boutin, A.; Coudert, F.-X. APL Mater. 2014, 2, 124110 DOI: 10.1063/1.4904818

      Thermal and mechanical stability of zeolitic imidazolate frameworks polymorphs
      Bouessel du Bourg, Lila; Ortiz, Aurelie U.; Boutin, Anne; Coudert, Francois-Xavier
      APL Materials (2014), 2 (12), 124110/1-124110/9CODEN: AMPADS; ISSN:2166-532X. (American Institute of Physics)
      Theor. studies on the exptl. feasibility of hypothetical Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks (ZIFs) have focused so far on relative energy of various polymorphs by energy minimization at the quantum chem. level. We present here a systematic study of stability of 18 ZIFs as a function of temp. and pressure by mol. dynamics simulations. This approach allows us to better understand the limited stability of some exptl. structures upon solvent or guest removal. We also find that many of the hypothetical ZIFs proposed in the literature are not stable at room temp. Mech. and thermal stability criteria thus need to be considered for the prediction of new MOF structures. Finally, we predict a variety of thermal expansion behavior for ZIFs as a function of framework topol., with some materials showing large neg. vol. thermal expansion. (c) 2014 American Institute of Physics.

      Yan, Y.; Yang, S.; Blake, A. J.; Schröder, M. Acc. Chem. Res. 2014, 47, 296– 307 DOI: 10.1021/ar400049h
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      20
      Studies on Metal-Organic Frameworks of Cu(II) with Isophthalate Linkers for Hydrogen Storage
      Yan, Yong; Yang, Sihai; Blake, Alexander J.; Schroder, Martin
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2014), 47 (2), 296-307CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. H (H2) is a promising alternative energy carrier because of its environmental benefits, high energy d., and abundance. However, development of a practical storage system to enable the H Economy remains a huge challenge. Metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) are an important class of cryst. coordination polymers constructed by bridging metal centers with org. linkers. MOFs show promise for H2 storage owing to their high surface area and tuneable properties. In this Account, the authors summarize the authors' research on novel porous materials with enhanced H2 storage properties and describe frameworks derived from 3,5-substituted dicarboxylates (isophthalates) that serve as versatile mol. building blocks for the construction of a range of interesting coordination polymers with Cu(II) ions. The authors synthesized materials by connecting linear tetracarboxylate linkers to {Cu(II)2} paddlewheel moieties. These materials exhibit high structural stability and permanent porosity. Varying the org. linker modulates the pore size, geometry, and functionality to control the overall H2 adsorption. The authors' top-performing material in this series has a H2 storage capacity of 77.8 mg g-1 at 77 K, 60 bar. H2 adsorption at low, medium, and high pressures correlates with the isosteric heat of adsorption, surface area, and pore vol., resp. Another series, using tribranched C3-sym. hexacarboxylate ligands with Cu(II), gives highly porous (3,24)-connected frameworks incorporating {Cu(II)2} paddlewheels. Increasing the length of the hexacarboxylate struts directly tunes the porosity of the resultant material from micro- to mesoporosity. These materials show exceptionally high H2 uptakes owing to their high surface area and pore vol. The 1st member of this family reported adsorbs 111 mg g-1 of H2, or 55.9 g L-1, at 77 K, 77 bar, while at 77 K, 1 bar, the material adsorbs 2.3 wt. ̂ H2. The authors and others have since achieved enhanced H2 adsorption in these frameworks using combinations of polyphenyl groups linked by alkynes. The max. storage achieved for one of the enhanced materials is 164 mg g-1 at 77 K, 70 bar, but because of its low d., its volumetric capacity is only 45.7 g L-1. The authors attribute the significant adsorption of H2 at low pressures to the arrangement of the {Cu24(isophthalate)24} cuboctahedral cages within the polyhedral structure. Free metal coordination positions are the 1st binding sites for D2, and these frameworks have two types of Cu(II) centers, one with its vacant site pointing into the cuboctahedral cage and another pointing externally. D2 mols. bind 1st at the former position and then at the external open metal sites. Design of ligands and complexes is key for enhancing and maximizing H2 storage, and although current materials operate at 77 K, research continues to explore routes to high capacity H2 storage materials that can function at higher temps.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhslSgtb%252FI&md5=cc8254d032b3130032ff7577e2a0615e
    21. 21
      (a) Dincă, M.; Long, J. R. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2008, 47, 6766– 6779 DOI: 10.1002/anie.200801163
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      21a
      Hydrogen storage in microporous metal-organic frameworks with exposed metal sites
      Dinca, Mircea; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2008), 47 (36), 6766-6779CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. Owing to their high uptake capacity at low temp. and excellent reversibility kinetics, metal-org. frameworks are potential solid-state H storage materials. Strategies for increasing the affinity of these materials towards H have been pursued and the binding of H2 to unsatd. metal centers is one of the most promising. The synthetic approaches employed far for producing frameworks with exposed metal sites are discussed as well as the H uptake capacities and binding energies in these materials. Results from expts. that were used to probe independently the metal-H interaction in selected materials are presented.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtV2iurrF&md5=2f4a240275f7eec477689d67e4fc0606

      21b
      Neutron Powder Diffraction Study of D2 Sorption in Cu3(1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate)2
      Peterson, Vanessa K.; Liu, Yun; Brown, Craig M.; Kepert, Cameron J.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (49), 15578-15579CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Rietveld analyses of neutron powder diffraction data of D2 in Cu3(BTC)2, where BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, reveals the location and progressive filling of 6 distinct D2 sites within the nanopore structure. Location of the primary site at the coordinatively unsatd. Cu atoms provides direct structural evidence of the potential importance of such metal sites to hydrogen storage. Competitive loading of the other D2 sites proceeds with the pores filling from smallest to largest.

      Hydrogen Sorption in Functionalized Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Millward, Andrew R.; Park, Kyo Sung; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (18), 5666-5667CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Five porous metal-org. frameworks based on linking zinc oxide clusters with benzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, naphthalene-2,6-dicarboxylate, 4,5,9,10-tetrahydropyrene-2,7-dicarboxylate, 2,3,5,6-tetramethylbenzene-1,4-dicarboxylate, or benzene-1,3,5-tris(4-benzoate) were synthesized in gram-scale quantities to measure their hydrogen uptake properties. Hydrogen adsorption isotherms measured at 77 K show a distinct dependence of uptake on the nature of the link. At 1 atm, the materials sorb between 4.2 and 9.3 mols. of H2 per formula unit. The results imply a trend in hydrogen uptake with the no. of rings in the org. moiety.

      (a) Peng, Y.; Krungleviciute, V.; Eryazici, I.; Hupp, J. T.; Farha, O. K.; Yildirim, T. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2013, 135, 11887– 11894 DOI: 10.1021/ja4045289
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23a
      Methane Storage in Metal-Organic Frameworks: Current Records, Surprise Findings, and Challenges
      Peng, Yang; Krungleviciute, Vaiva; Eryazici, Ibrahim; Hupp, Joseph T.; Farha, Omar K.; Yildirim, Taner
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2013), 135 (32), 11887-11894CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors have examd. the methane uptake properties of 6 of the most promising metal org. framework (MOF) materials: PCN-14, UTSA-20, HKUST-1, Ni-MOF-74 (Ni-CPO-27), NU-111, and NU-125. HKUST-1, a material that is com. available in gram scale, exhibits a room-temp. volumetric methane uptake that exceeds any value reported to date. The total uptake is ∼230 cc(STP)/cc at 35 bar and 270 cc(STP)/cc at 65 bar, which meets the new volumetric target recently set by the Department of Energy (DOE) if the packing efficiency loss is ignored. The authors emphasize that MOFs with high surface areas and pore vols. perform better overall. NU-111, for example, reaches ∼75% of both the gravimetric and the volumetric targets. Values for gravimetric uptake, pore vol., and inverse d. of the MOFs the authors studied scale essentially linearly with surface area. From this linear dependence, the authors est. that a MOF with surface area 7500 m2/g and pore vol. 3.2 cc/g could reach the current DOE gravimetric target of 0.5 g/g while simultaneously exhibiting around ∼200 cc/cc volumetric uptake. While values for volumetric uptake are based on ideal single crystal densities, in reality the packing densities of MOFs are much lower. Finally, compacting HKUST-1 into wafer shapes partially collapses the framework, decreasing both volumetric and gravimetric uptake significantly. Hence, one of the important challenges going forward is to find ways to pack MOFs efficiently without serious damage or to synthesize MOFs that can withstand substantial mech. pressure.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtV2msbrN&md5=23f9bfad78f204569f0bf7c902d42dca
      (b) He, Y.; Zhou, W.; Yildirim, T.; Chen, B. Energy Environ. Sci. 2013, 6, 2735– 2744 DOI: 10.1039/c3ee41166d
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      23b
      A series of metal-organic frameworks with high methane uptake and an empirical equation for predicting methane storage capacity
      He, Yabing; Zhou, Wei; Yildirim, Taner; Chen, Banglin
      Energy & Environmental Science (2013), 6 (9), 2735-2744CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A series of metal-org. frameworks (NOTT-100a (MOF-505a), NOTT-101a, NOTT-102a, NOTT-103a and NOTT-109a) with variable open copper sites and micropore spaces have been examd. as potential adsorbents for methane storage. They exhibit high adsorption capacities for methane at 300 K and 35 bar (181-196 cm3 (STP) cm-3). Supposing that the deliverable amt. of methane is defined as the difference in the amt. of methane adsorbed between 5 bar and 35 bar, NOTT-101a, NOTT-102a and NOTT-103a exhibit excellent deliverable capacities of methane (136-140 cm3 (STP) cm-3), comparable to the highest of all previously reported MOF materials. The gravimetric methane uptake in this MOF series systematically increases with increasing porosity, while their methane storage pore occupancy decreases with increasing pore size. The fact that gravimetric methane uptakes correlate well with their corresponding pore vols. enables us to derive an empirical equation: C = -126.69 × Vp2 + 381.62 × Vp - 12.57, where C is the excess gravimetric methane storage capacity at 35 bar and 300 K in cm3 (STP) g-1, and Vp is the pore vol. of a MOF material in cm3 g-1. This empirical equation can predict the methane storage performance of previously reported microporous MOF materials of Vp less than 1.50 cm3 g-1 reasonably well, and thus provides a convenient method to screen MOFs for methane storage purposes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtlWqsr3P&md5=831d08421af598dfb94019b012e4ed3f

      Designing Higher Surface Area Metal-Organic Frameworks: Are Triple Bonds Better Than Phenyls?
      Farha, Omar K.; Wilmer, Christopher E.; Eryazici, Ibrahim; Hauser, Brad G.; Parilla, Philip A.; O'Neill, Kevin; Sarjeant, Amy A.; Nguyen, SonBinh T.; Snurr, Randall Q.; Hupp, Joseph T.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2012), 134 (24), 9860-9863CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors have synthesized, characterized, and computationally validated the high Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area and hydrogen uptake of a new, non-catenating metal-org. framework (MOF) material, NU-111. The results imply that replacing the Ph spacers of org. linkers with triple-bond spacers is an effective strategy for boosting mol.-accessible gravimetric surface areas of MOFs and related high-porosity materials.

      Analysis of High and Selective Uptake of CO2 in an Oxamide-Containing {Cu2(OOCR)4}-Based Metal-Organic Framework
      Alsmail, Nada H.; Suyetin, Mikhail; Yan, Yong; Cabot, Rafel; Krap, Cristina P.; Lue, Jian; Easun, Timothy L.; Bichoutskaia, Elena; Lewis, William; Blake, Alexander J.; Schroeder, Martin
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2014), 20 (24), 7317-7324CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The porous framework [Cu2(H2O)2L].4H2O.2DMA (H4L = oxalylbis(azanediyl)diisophthalic acid; DMA = N,N-dimethylacetamide), denoted NOTT-125, is formed by connection of {Cu2(RCOO)4} paddlewheels with the isophthalate linkers in L4-. A single crystal structure detn. reveals that NOTT-125 crystallizes in monoclinic unit cell with a 27.9161(6), b 18.6627(4) and c 32.3643(8) Å, β 112.655(3)°, space group P21/c. The structure of this material shows fof topol., which can be viewed as the packing of two types of cages (cage A and cage B) in three-dimensional space. Cage A is constructed from twelve {Cu2(OOCR)4} paddlewheels and six linkers to form an ellipsoid-shaped cavity ∼24.0 Å along its long axis and 9.6 Å across its central diam. Cage B consists of six {Cu2(OOCR)4} units and twelve linkers and has a spherical diam. of 12.7 Å taking into account the van der Waals radii of the atoms. NOTT-125 incorporates oxamide functionality within the pore walls, and this, combined with high porosity in desolvated NOTT-125a, is responsible for excellent CO2 uptake (40.1% at 273 K and 1 bar) and selectivity for CO2 over CH4 or N2. Grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations show excellent agreement with the exptl. gas isotherm data, and a computational study of the specific interactions and binding energies of both CO2 and CH4 with the linkers in NOTT-125 reveals a set of strong interactions between CO2 and the oxamide motif that are not possible with a single amide.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXnsFWmtr0%253D&md5=aa02b4280669c57df6e006d3537391cb

      Control of Pore Size and Functionality in Isoreticular Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks and their Carbon Dioxide Selective Capture Properties
      Banerjee, Rahul; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Britt, David; Knobler, Carolyn; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (11), 3875-3877CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Five new cryst. zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), ZIF-78 to -82, were prepd. from zinc(II) nitrate and mixts. of 2-nitroimidazole and five different functionalized imidazoles and were found to have the GME topol. These structures, along with three previously reported GME ZIFs, constitute a series of highly porous materials with Brunauer-Emmet-Teller surface areas ranging from 620 to 1730 m2/g. The pore diams. and apertures vary incrementally from 7.1 to 15.9 Å and 3.8 to 13.1 Å, resp., and the functionalities decorating the pores vary from polar cyano- and nitro- groups to nonpolar alkyl groups. The variability expressed in these materials makes them highly attractive for study as gas-sepn. media. Selectivity values calcd. for sepn. of CO2 and CH4 predict that the ZIFs with polar functionality, ZIF-78 (10.6:1) and -82 (9.6:1), retain CO2 gas to a greater degree than the other members of the GME series and BPL-activated carbon. These predictions are borne out in dynamic breakthrough studies, which confirm the increased capacity of ZIF-78 and -82 and demonstrate the promise of this class of materials.

      A Combined Experimental-Computational Investigation of Carbon Dioxide Capture in a Series of Isoreticular Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks
      Morris, William; Leung, Belinda; Furukawa, Hiroyasu; Yaghi, Omar K.; He, Ning; Hayashi, Hideki; Houndonougbo, Yao; Asta, Mark; Laird, Brian B.; Yaghi, Omar M.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (32), 11006-11008CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A series of five zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) have been synthesized using zinc(II) acetate and five different 4,5-functionalized imidazole units, namely ZIF-25, -71, -93, -96, and -97. These 3-D porous frameworks have the same underlying topol. (RHO) with Brunauer-Emmet-Teller surface areas ranging from 564 to 1110 m2/g. The only variation in structure arises from the functional groups that are directed into the pores of these materials, which include -CH3, -OH, -Cl, -CN, -CHO, and -NH2; therefore these 3-D frameworks are ideal for the study of the effect of functionality on CO2 uptake. Exptl. results show CO2 uptake at approx. 800 Torr and 298 K ranging from 0.65 mmol g-1 in ZIF-71 to 2.18 mmol g-1 in ZIF-96. Mol. modeling calcns. reproduce the pronounced dependence of the equil. adsorption on functionalization and suggest that polarizability and symmetry of the functionalization on the imidazolate are key factors leading to high CO2 uptake.

      28a
      Commensurate Adsorption of Hydrocarbons and Alcohols in Microporous Metal Organic Frameworks
      Wu, Haohan; Gong, Qihan; Olson, David H.; Li, Jing
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 112 (2), 836-868CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Commensurate adsorption is an interesting and important phenomenon occurring during adsorption processes, where the mol. size and shape of the adsorbate (guest mol.) lead to an orientation and adsorbed amt. (at equil.) that is compatible and self-consistent with the crystal symmetry and pore structure of the adsorbent. As a new type of adsorbate material with distinctly advantageous features, microporous metal org. frameworks (MMOFs) demonstrate enormous potential for adsorption based applications, including storage, sepn., and purifn. of small gases and hydrocarbons. Commensurate adsorption of hydrocarbons occurs far more often in MMOFs than in zeolites and related materials, primarily as a result of a vastly greater variety of framework types and richer hierarchy of complexity of the pore structures for the former. Among numerous structures in which commensurate adsorption has been obsd. in the vicinity of room temp., many have 1D open channels built on pore segments of distinct shape, size, and narrow pore window that closely match with the geometries of hydrocarbon species.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Microporous metal-organic frameworks for storage and separation of small hydrocarbons
      He, Yabing; Zhou, Wei; Krishna, Rajamani; Chen, Banglin

      A review. Hydrocarbons are very important energy resources and raw materials for some industrially important products and fine chems. There is a need for the discovery of better materials that offer enhanced capacities for safe storage of hydrocarbons. Furthermore, the development of improved sepn. technologies will lead to significant redn. in energy requirements and costs. In this feature article, we provide an overview of the current status of the emerging microporous metal-org. frameworks for the storage and sepn. of small hydrocarbons.

      Hydrocarbon Separations in a Metal-Organic Framework with Open Iron(II) Coordination Sites
      Bloch, Eric D.; Queen, Wendy L.; Krishna, Rajamani; Zadrozny, Joseph M.; Brown, Craig M.; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 335 (6076), 1606-1610CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      The energy costs assocd. with large-scale industrial sepn. of light hydrocarbons by cryogenic distn. could potentially be lowered through development of selective solid adsorbents that operate at higher temps. Here, the metal-org. framework Fe2(dobdc) (dobdc4- : 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) is demonstrated to exhibit excellent performance characteristics for sepn. of ethylene/ethane and propylene/propane mixts. at 318 K. Breakthrough data obtained for these mixts. provide exptl. validation of simulations, which in turn predict high selectivities and capacities of this material for the fractionation of methane/ethane/ethylene/acetylene mixts., removal of acetylene impurities from ethylene, and membrane-based olefin/paraffin sepns. Neutron powder diffraction data confirm a side-on coordination of acetylene, ethylene, and propylene at the iron(II) centers, while also providing solid-state structural characterization of the much weaker interactions of ethane and propane with the metal.

      Hydrocarbon Separations in Metal-Organic Frameworks
      Herm, Zoey R.; Bloch, Eric D.; Long, Jeffrey R.
      Chemistry of Materials (2014), 26 (1), 323-338CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. New materials capable of sepg. mixts. of satd., unsatd., and arom. hydrocarbons can enable more efficient industrial processes and cleaner energy. Outstanding challenges in hydrocarbon sepns. stem from the similar structures, properties, and reactivities of the mols. comprising many of these mixts. With high surface areas, tunable pore geometries, and adjustable surface functionality, metal-org. frameworks hold tremendous promise for effecting previously difficult or impossible sepns. In this review, the authors provide a comprehensive account of the metal-org. frameworks that were studied for hydrocarbon sepns. within the context of their potential relevance for sepg. various industrial alkane-, alkene-, and arom.-contg. mixts.

      A New Approach to Construct a Doubly Interpenetrated Microporous Metal-Organic Framework of Primitive Cubic Net for Highly Selective Sorption of Small Hydrocarbon Molecules
      Das, Madhab C.; Xu, Hui; Xiang, Sheng-Chang; Zhang, Zhang-Jing; Arman, Hadi D.; Qian, Guo-Dong; Chen, Bang-Lin
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2011), 17 (28), 7817-7822, S7817/1-S7817/4CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A new approach was realized to construct a three-dimensional doubly interpenetrated cubic metal-org. framework Zn2(PBA)2(BDC)·(DMF)3(H2O)4 (UTSA-36, HPBA = 4-(4-pyridyl)benzoic acid, H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid) through the self-assembly of the pyridylcarboxylate linker 4-(4-pyridyl)benzoate and bicarboxylate linker 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate with paddle-wheel [Zn2(COO)4]. The activated UTSA-36 a exhibits highly selective gas sorption of C2H6, C2H4 and C2H2 over CH4 with the Henry law's selectivities of 11 to 25 at 273-296 K attributed to the unique 3-dimensional intersected pore structure of ∼3.1 to 4.8 Å within the framework, indicating that UTSA-36 a is a potentially very useful and promising microporous material for such industrially important sepn. of C2 hydrocarbons over methane.

      (d) Xiang, S. C.; Zhang, Z. J.; Zhao, C. G.; Hong, K.; Zhao, X. B.; Ding, D. R.; Xie, M. H.; Wu, C. D.; Das, M. C.; Gill, R.; Thomas, K. M.; Chen, B. Nat. Commun. 2011, 2, 204– 209 DOI: 10.1038/ncomms1206

      Rationally tuned micropores within enantiopure metal-organic frameworks for highly selective separation of acetylene and ethylene
      Xiang Sheng-Chang; Zhang Zhangjing; Zhao Cong-Gui; Hong Kunlun; Zhao Xuebo; Ding De-Rong; Xie Ming-Hua; Wu Chuan-De; Das Madhab C; Gill Rachel; Thomas K Mark; Chen Banglin
      Nature communications (2011), 2 (), 204 ISSN:.
      Separation of acetylene and ethylene is an important industrial process because both compounds are essential reagents for a range of chemical products and materials. Current separation approaches include the partial hydrogenation of acetylene into ethylene over a supported Pd catalyst, and the extraction of cracked olefins using an organic solvent; both routes are costly and energy consuming. Adsorption technologies may allow separation, but microporous materials exhibiting highly selective adsorption of C(2)H(2)/C(2)H(4) have not been realized to date. Here, we report the development of tunable microporous enantiopure mixed-metal-organic framework (M'MOF) materials for highly selective separation of C(2)H(2) and C(2)H(4). The high selectivities achieved suggest the potential application of microporous M'MOFs for practical adsorption-based separation of C(2)H(2)/C(2)H(4).

      Matsuda, R.; Kitaura, R.; Kitagawa, S.; Kubota, Y.; Belosludov, R. V.; Kobayashi, T. C.; Sakamoto, H.; Chiba, T.; Takata, M.; Kawazoe, Y.; Mita, Y. Nature 2005, 436, 238– 241 DOI: 10.1038/nature03852
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      30
      Highly controlled acetylene accommodation in a metal-organic microporous material
      Matsuda, Ryotaro; Kitaura, Ryo; Kitagawa, Susumu; Kubota, Yoshiki; Belosludov, Rodion V.; Kobayashi, Tatsuo C.; Sakamoto, Hirotoshi; Chiba, Takashi; Takata, Masaki; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki; Mita, Yoshimi
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2005), 436 (7048), 238-241CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Metal-org. microporous materials (MOMs) have attracted wide scientific attention owing to their unusual structure and properties, as well as com. interest due to their potential applications in storage, sepn. and heterogeneous catalysis. One of the advantages of MOMs compared to other microporous materials, such as activated carbons, is their ability to exhibit a variety of pore surface properties such as hydrophilicity and chirality, as a result of the controlled incorporation of org. functional groups into the pore walls. This capability means that the pore surfaces of MOMs could be designed to adsorb specific mols.; but few design strategies for the adsorption of small mols. have been established so far. Here we report high levels of selective sorption of acetylene mols. as compared to a very similar mol., carbon dioxide, onto the functionalized surface of a MOM. The acetylene mols. are held at a periodic distance from one another by hydrogen bonding between two non-coordinated oxygen atoms in the nanoscale pore wall of the MOM and the two hydrogen atoms of the acetylene mol. This permits the stable storage of acetylene at a d. 200 times the safe compression limit of free acetylene at room temp.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXmtVers7o%253D&md5=33d1004f5e9fc5dff5fe8327ebc502d7
    31. 31
      (a) Xiang, S.; Zhou, W.; Gallegos, J. M.; Liu, Y.; Chen, B. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 12415– 12419 DOI: 10.1021/ja904782h
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31a
      Exceptionally High Acetylene Uptake in a Microporous Metal-Organic Framework with Open Metal Sites
      Xiang, Shengchang; Zhou, Wei; Gallegos, Jose M.; Liu, Yun; Chen, Banglin
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (34), 12415-12419CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      Six prototype microporous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) HKUST-1, MOF-505, MOF-508, MIL-53, MOF-5, and ZIF-8 with variable structures and porosities were examd. for their acetylene storage, highlighting HKUST-1 as the highest acetylene storage material ever reported with an uptake of 201 cm3/g at 295 K and 1 atm. To locate the acetylene binding sites within HKUST-1, neutron powder diffraction studies on acetylene loaded HKUST-1 were carried out and have conclusively established the significant contribution of open Cu2+ sites for acetylene storage by their strong preferred interactions with acetylene mols. The binding properties of acetylene gas at different sites were further studied by 1st-principles calcns.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXpsFyit7s%253D&md5=9633872bb4317bfce1df9f27fb6fdd2e
      (b) He, Y.; Krishna, R.; Chen, B. Energy Environ. Sci. 2012, 5, 9107– 9120 DOI: 10.1039/c2ee22858k
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31b
      Metal-organic frameworks with potential for energy-efficient adsorptive separation of light hydrocarbons
      He, Yabing; Krishna, Rajamani; Chen, Banglin
      Energy & Environmental Science (2012), 5 (10), 9107-9120CODEN: EESNBY; ISSN:1754-5706. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The sepn. of hydrocarbons with carbon nos. in the 1-3 range is of great significance in the purifn. of natural gas, prodn. of ethylene and propylene with the required 99.5%+ purity levels as feeds to polymn. reactors, and sepn. of ethyne from mixts. with ethylene. In this study the performances of a total of 19 different MOFs, carefully selected to span a wide range of functionalities, were evaluated for a variety of sepn. tasks. For all sepn. tasks investigated, MOFs with high d. of open metal sites, CoMOF-74, MgMOF-74, and FeMOF-74, have significantly better sepn. potential than other MOFs, ZIFs or zeolites that have been suggested in the literature. Of particular significance is the possibility offered by CoMOF-74, MgMOF-74, and FeMOF-74 for "fractionating" a 6-component CH4/C2H2/C2H4/C2H6/C3H6/C3H8 mixt. to yield individual pure components. Such sepns. are likely to have a significant industrial impact, resulting in significant energy savings when compared to current technologies that rely on distn.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38Xhtlyqs7nJ&md5=60d67294ba300e1137a47779c3689b1e
    32. 32
      Xiang, S.; Zhou, W.; Zhang, Z.; Green, M. A.; Liu, Y.; Chen, B. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2010, 49, 4615– 4618 DOI: 10.1002/anie.201000094
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32
      Open Metal Sites within Isostructural Metal-Organic Frameworks for Differential Recognition of Acetylene and Extraordinarily High Acetylene Storage Capacity at Room Temperature
      Xiang, Shengchang; Zhou, Wei; Zhang, Zhangjing; Green, Mark A.; Liu, Yun; Chen, Banglin
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2010), 49 (27), 4615-4618, S4615/1-S4615/17CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A series of isostructural metal-org. frameworks with open metal sites were examd. for their differential recognition of acetylene mols. The open metal sites within them exhibit the interaction in which cobalt ion has the strongest interaction with acetylene and a high adsorption enthalpy. This high capacity maximizes the safe acetylene storage d. in bulk materials.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXnvVOrsrs%253D&md5=9b2b4d7c4bf404e26193e2a4195f3db8
    33. 33
      He, Y.; Zhang, Z.; Xiang, S.; Wu, H.; Fronczek, F. R.; Zhou, W.; Krishna, R.; O’Keeffe, M.; Chen, B. Chem. - Eur. J. 2012, 18, 1901– 1904 DOI: 10.1002/chem.201103927
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      33
      High Separation Capacity and Selectivity of C2 Hydrocarbons over Methane within a Microporous Metal-Organic Framework at Room Temperature
      He, Yabing; Zhang, Zhangjing; Xiang, Shengchang; Wu, Hui; Fronczek, Frank R.; Zhou, Wei; Krishna, Rajamani; O'Keeffe, Michael; Chen, Banglin
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (7), 1901-1904, S1901/1-S1901/25CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A newly prepd. copper org. framework [Cu3(H2L)(H2O)3]·3DEF·2.5H2O (H8L = 1,2,4,5-tetra(5-isophthalate)benzene; UTSA-34, UTSA = University of Texas at San Antonio) is constructed from the paddlewheel Cu2(CO2)4 secondary building units and the expanded octacarboxylate org. linkers as characterized by crystal structure anal. The permanent microporosities were established for both partially UTSA-34a and completely desolvated MOFs UTSA-34b and their C1 and C2 hydrocarbon sorption isotherms were measured to establish their potential for selective sepn. The authors further examd. the sepn. selectivity and capacity of UTSA-34b for C2H2/CH4, C2H4/CH4, and C2H6/CH4 binary mixts. at 296 K. Such high sepn. capacity and selectivity are attributed to the moderately high pore spaces within the framework to take up a large amt. of hydrocarbons and open Cu metal sites on the pore surfaces for their stronger interactions with C2H2 and C2H4.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtFait7s%253D&md5=881d2d75f705c46efdaa276537091ae4

      1. 1
        (a) Lin, X.; Jia, J.; Hubberstey, P.; Schröder, M.; Champness, N. R. CrystEngComm 2007, 9, 438– 448 DOI: 10.1039/b706207a
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1a
        Hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
        Lin, Xiang; Jia, Junhua; Hubberstey, Peter; Schroder, Martin; Champness, Neil R.
        CrystEngComm (2007), 9 (6), 438-448CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review, with 74 refs. The role of porous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) as storage materials for H (H2) and the current state-of-the-art in this rapidly developing field are reviewed. The significant potential of MOFs to effectively and reversibly store H2 illustrates the great promise that crystal engineering of solid-state materials gives to the next generation of applied multi-functional materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXntlGgsbk%253D&md5=686e9af817f1e23d71119ab786f95a1e
        (b) Dincă, M.; Long, J. R. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2008, 47, 6766– 6779 DOI: 10.1002/anie.200801163
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1b
        Hydrogen storage in microporous metal-organic frameworks with exposed metal sites
        Dinca, Mircea; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2008), 47 (36), 6766-6779CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Owing to their high uptake capacity at low temp. and excellent reversibility kinetics, metal-org. frameworks are potential solid-state H storage materials. Strategies for increasing the affinity of these materials towards H have been pursued and the binding of H2 to unsatd. metal centers is one of the most promising. The synthetic approaches employed far for producing frameworks with exposed metal sites are discussed as well as the H uptake capacities and binding energies in these materials. Results from expts. that were used to probe independently the metal-H interaction in selected materials are presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhtV2iurrF&md5=2f4a240275f7eec477689d67e4fc0606
        (c) Murray, L. J.; Dincă, M.; Long, J. R. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2009, 38, 1294– 1314 DOI: 10.1039/b802256a
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1c
        Hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
        Murray, Leslie J.; Dinca, Mircea; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1294-1314CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review of current status of hydrogen storage within metal-org. frameworks. Microporous metal-org. frameworks, having exceptionally high surface areas and chem.-tunable structures, have recently emerged as some of the most promising candidate materials. Particular emphasis is given to the relationships between structural features and the enthalpy of hydrogen adsorption, spectroscopic methods for probing framework-H2 interactions, and strategies for improving storage capacity.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXkvVamuro%253D&md5=f652ac03772753d7f80244564a80e6f0
